trans-unit.source: Configure PHP in Azure App Service Web Apps
trans-unit.target: Configure PHP in Azure App Service Web Apps

trans-unit.source: Learn how to configure the default PHP installation or add a custom PHP installation for Web Apps in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to configure the default PHP installation or add a custom PHP installation for Web Apps in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: Configure PHP in Azure App Service Web Apps
trans-unit.target: Configure PHP in Azure App Service Web Apps

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: This guide will show you how to configure the built-in PHP runtime for Web Apps in <link><linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, provide a custom PHP runtime, and enable extensions.
trans-unit.target: This guide will show you how to configure the built-in PHP runtime for Web Apps in <link><linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, provide a custom PHP runtime, and enable extensions.

trans-unit.source: To use App Service, sign up for the [free trial].
trans-unit.target: To use App Service, sign up for the [free trial].

trans-unit.source: To get the most from this guide, you should first create a PHP web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: To get the most from this guide, you should first create a PHP web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: How to: Change the built-in PHP version
trans-unit.target: How to: Change the built-in PHP version

trans-unit.source: By default, PHP 5.4 is installed and immediately available for use when you create an App Service web app.
trans-unit.target: By default, PHP 5.4 is installed and immediately available for use when you create an App Service web app.

trans-unit.source: The best way to see the available release revision, its default configuration, and the enabled extensions is to deploy a script that calls the [phpinfo()] function.
trans-unit.target: The best way to see the available release revision, its default configuration, and the enabled extensions is to deploy a script that calls the [phpinfo()] function.

trans-unit.source: PHP 5.5 and PHP 5.6 versions are also available, but not enabled by default.
trans-unit.target: PHP 5.5 and PHP 5.6 versions are also available, but not enabled by default.

trans-unit.source: To update the PHP version, follow one of these methods:
trans-unit.target: To update the PHP version, follow one of these methods:

trans-unit.source: Azure Portal
trans-unit.target: Azure Portal

trans-unit.source: Browse to your web app in the Azure Portal and click on the Settings button.
trans-unit.target: Browse to your web app in the Azure Portal and click on the Settings button.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Web App Settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Web App Settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: From the Settings blade select Application Settings and choose the new PHP version.
trans-unit.target: From the Settings blade select Application Settings and choose the new PHP version.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Application Settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Application Settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the Save button at the top of the Web app settings blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the Save button at the top of the Web app settings blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Save configuration settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Save configuration settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell (Windows)
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell (Windows)

trans-unit.source: Open Windows PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Open Windows PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Type Set-AzureWebsite -PhpVersion [5.4 | 5.5 | 5.6] -Name then press enter.
trans-unit.target: Type Set-AzureWebsite -PhpVersion [5.4 | 5.5 | 5.6] -Name then press enter.

trans-unit.source: The PHP version is now set.
trans-unit.target: The PHP version is now set.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Setting the PHP version with Azure PowerShell</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Setting the PHP version with Azure PowerShell</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can confirm these settings by typing Get-AzureWebiste -Name then press enter.
trans-unit.target: You can confirm these settings by typing Get-AzureWebiste -Name then press enter.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Verifying the PHP version with Azure PowerShell</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Verifying the PHP version with Azure PowerShell</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Azure Command-Line Interface (Linux, Mac, Windows)
trans-unit.target: Azure Command-Line Interface (Linux, Mac, Windows)

trans-unit.source: To use the Azure Command-Line Interface, you must have Node.js installed on your computer.
trans-unit.target: To use the Azure Command-Line Interface, you must have Node.js installed on your computer.

trans-unit.source: Open Terminal.
trans-unit.target: Open Terminal.

trans-unit.source: Type azure site set --php-version [5.4 | 5.5] [site-name] then press enter.
trans-unit.target: Type azure site set --php-version [5.4 | 5.5] [site-name] then press enter.

trans-unit.source: The PHP version is now set.
trans-unit.target: The PHP version is now set.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Setting the PHP version with Azure Command-Line Interface</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Setting the PHP version with Azure Command-Line Interface</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can confirm these settings by typing azure site show [site-name] then press enter.
trans-unit.target: You can confirm these settings by typing azure site show [site-name] then press enter.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Verifying the PHP version with Azure Command-Line Interface</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Verifying the PHP version with Azure Command-Line Interface</linkText>

trans-unit.source: How to: Change the built-in PHP configurations
trans-unit.target: How to: Change the built-in PHP configurations

trans-unit.source: For any built-in PHP runtime, you can change any of the configuration options by following the steps below.
trans-unit.target: For any built-in PHP runtime, you can change any of the configuration options by following the steps below.

trans-unit.source: (For information about php.ini directives, see [List of php.ini directives].)
trans-unit.target: (For information about php.ini directives, see [List of php.ini directives].)

trans-unit.source: Changing PHP\_INI\_USER, PHP\_INI\_PERDIR, PHP\_INI\_ALL configuration settings
trans-unit.target: Changing PHP\_INI\_USER, PHP\_INI\_PERDIR, PHP\_INI\_ALL configuration settings

trans-unit.source: Add a [.user.ini] file to your root directory.
trans-unit.target: Add a [.user.ini] file to your root directory.

trans-unit.source: Add configuration settings to the .user.ini file using the same syntax you would use in a php.ini file.
trans-unit.target: Add configuration settings to the .user.ini file using the same syntax you would use in a php.ini file.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you wanted to turn the display_errors setting on and set upload_max_filesize setting to 10M, your .user.ini file would contain this text:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you wanted to turn the display_errors setting on and set upload_max_filesize setting to 10M, your .user.ini file would contain this text:

trans-unit.source: Deploy your web app.
trans-unit.target: Deploy your web app.

trans-unit.source: Restart the web app.
trans-unit.target: Restart the web app.

trans-unit.source: (Restarting is necessary because the frequency with which PHP reads .user.ini files is governed by the user_ini.cache_ttl setting, which is a system level setting and is 300 seconds (5 minutes) by default.
trans-unit.target: (Restarting is necessary because the frequency with which PHP reads .user.ini files is governed by the user_ini.cache_ttl setting, which is a system level setting and is 300 seconds (5 minutes) by default.

trans-unit.source: Restarting the web app forces PHP to read the new settings in the .user.ini file.)
trans-unit.target: Restarting the web app forces PHP to read the new settings in the .user.ini file.)

trans-unit.source: As an alternative to using a .user.ini file, you can use the [ini_set()] function in scripts to set configuration options that are not system-level directives.
trans-unit.target: As an alternative to using a .user.ini file, you can use the [ini_set()] function in scripts to set configuration options that are not system-level directives.

trans-unit.source: Changing PHP\_INI\_SYSTEM configuration settings
trans-unit.target: Changing PHP\_INI\_SYSTEM configuration settings

trans-unit.source: Add an App Setting to your Web App with the key PHP_INI_SCAN_DIR and value d:\home\site\ini
trans-unit.target: Add an App Setting to your Web App with the key PHP_INI_SCAN_DIR and value d:\home\site\ini

trans-unit.source: Create an settings.ini file using Kudu Console (http://.scm.azurewebsite.net) in the d:\home\site\ini directory.
trans-unit.target: Create an settings.ini file using Kudu Console (http://.scm.azurewebsite.net) in the d:\home\site\ini directory.

trans-unit.source: Add configuration settings to the settings.ini file using the same syntax you would use in a php.ini file.
trans-unit.target: Add configuration settings to the settings.ini file using the same syntax you would use in a php.ini file.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you wanted to point the curl.cainfo setting to a *.crt file and set 'wincache.maxfilesize' setting to 512K, your settings.ini file would contain this text:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you wanted to point the curl.cainfo setting to a *.crt file and set 'wincache.maxfilesize' setting to 512K, your settings.ini file would contain this text:

trans-unit.source: Restart your Web App to load the changes.
trans-unit.target: Restart your Web App to load the changes.

trans-unit.source: How to: Enable extensions in the default PHP runtime
trans-unit.target: How to: Enable extensions in the default PHP runtime

trans-unit.source: As noted in the previous section, the best way to see the default PHP version, its default configuration, and the enabled extensions is to deploy a script that calls [phpinfo()].
trans-unit.target: As noted in the previous section, the best way to see the default PHP version, its default configuration, and the enabled extensions is to deploy a script that calls [phpinfo()].

trans-unit.source: To enable additional extensions, follow the steps below:
trans-unit.target: To enable additional extensions, follow the steps below:

trans-unit.source: Configure via ini settings
trans-unit.target: Configure via ini settings

trans-unit.source: Add a ext directory to the d:\home\site directory.
trans-unit.target: Add a ext directory to the d:\home\site directory.

trans-unit.source: Put .dll extension files in the ext directory (for example, php_mongo.dll and php_xdebug.dll).
trans-unit.target: Put .dll extension files in the ext directory (for example, php_mongo.dll and php_xdebug.dll).

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the extensions are compatible with default version of PHP (which is, as of this writing, PHP 5.4) and are VC9 and non-thread-safe (nts) compatible.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the extensions are compatible with default version of PHP (which is, as of this writing, PHP 5.4) and are VC9 and non-thread-safe (nts) compatible.

trans-unit.source: Add an App Setting to your Web App with the key PHP_INI_SCAN_DIR and value d:\home\site\ini
trans-unit.target: Add an App Setting to your Web App with the key PHP_INI_SCAN_DIR and value d:\home\site\ini

trans-unit.source: Create an ini file in d:\home\site\ini called extensions.ini.
trans-unit.target: Create an ini file in d:\home\site\ini called extensions.ini.

trans-unit.source: Add configuration settings to the extensions.ini file using the same syntax you would use in a php.ini file.
trans-unit.target: Add configuration settings to the extensions.ini file using the same syntax you would use in a php.ini file.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you wanted to enable the MongoDB and XDebug extensions, your extensions.ini file would contain this text:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you wanted to enable the MongoDB and XDebug extensions, your extensions.ini file would contain this text:

trans-unit.source: Restart your Web App to load the changes.
trans-unit.target: Restart your Web App to load the changes.

trans-unit.source: Configure via App Setting
trans-unit.target: Configure via App Setting

trans-unit.source: Add a bin directory to the root directory.
trans-unit.target: Add a bin directory to the root directory.

trans-unit.source: Put .dll extension files in the bin directory (for example, php_mongo.dll).
trans-unit.target: Put .dll extension files in the bin directory (for example, php_mongo.dll).

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the extensions are compatible with default version of PHP (which is, as of this writing, PHP 5.4) and are VC9 and non-thread-safe (nts) compatible.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the extensions are compatible with default version of PHP (which is, as of this writing, PHP 5.4) and are VC9 and non-thread-safe (nts) compatible.

trans-unit.source: Deploy your web app.
trans-unit.target: Deploy your web app.

trans-unit.source: Browse to your web app in the Azure Portal and click on the Settings button.
trans-unit.target: Browse to your web app in the Azure Portal and click on the Settings button.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Web App Settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Web App Settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: From the Settings blade select Application Settings and scroll to the App settings section.
trans-unit.target: From the Settings blade select Application Settings and scroll to the App settings section.

trans-unit.source: In the App settings section, create a PHP_EXTENSIONS key.
trans-unit.target: In the App settings section, create a PHP_EXTENSIONS key.

trans-unit.source: The value for this key would be a path relative to website root: bin\your-ext-file.
trans-unit.target: The value for this key would be a path relative to website root: bin\your-ext-file.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Enable extension in app settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Enable extension in app settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the Save button at the top of the Web app settings blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the Save button at the top of the Web app settings blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Save configuration settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Save configuration settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Zend extensions are also supported by using a PHP_ZENDEXTENSIONS key.
trans-unit.target: Zend extensions are also supported by using a PHP_ZENDEXTENSIONS key.

trans-unit.source: To enable multiple extensions, include a comma-separated list of .dll files for the app setting value.
trans-unit.target: To enable multiple extensions, include a comma-separated list of .dll files for the app setting value.

trans-unit.source: How to: Use a custom PHP runtime
trans-unit.target: How to: Use a custom PHP runtime

trans-unit.source: Instead of the default PHP runtime, App Service Web Apps can use a PHP runtime that you provide to execute PHP scripts.
trans-unit.target: Instead of the default PHP runtime, App Service Web Apps can use a PHP runtime that you provide to execute PHP scripts.

trans-unit.source: The runtime that you provide can be configured by a php.ini file that you also provide.
trans-unit.target: The runtime that you provide can be configured by a php.ini file that you also provide.

trans-unit.source: To use a custom PHP runtime with Web Apps, follow the steps below.
trans-unit.target: To use a custom PHP runtime with Web Apps, follow the steps below.

trans-unit.source: Obtain a non-thread-safe, VC9 or VC11 compatible version of PHP for Windows.
trans-unit.target: Obtain a non-thread-safe, VC9 or VC11 compatible version of PHP for Windows.

trans-unit.source: Recent releases of PHP for Windows can be found here: [http://windows.php.net/download/].
trans-unit.target: Recent releases of PHP for Windows can be found here: [http://windows.php.net/download/].

trans-unit.source: Older releases can be found in the archive here: [http://windows.php.net/downloads/releases/archives/].
trans-unit.target: Older releases can be found in the archive here: [http://windows.php.net/downloads/releases/archives/].

trans-unit.source: Modify the php.ini file for your runtime.
trans-unit.target: Modify the php.ini file for your runtime.

trans-unit.source: Note that any configuration settings that are system-level-only directives will be ignored by Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: Note that any configuration settings that are system-level-only directives will be ignored by Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: (For information about system-level-only directives, see [List of php.ini directives]).
trans-unit.target: (For information about system-level-only directives, see [List of php.ini directives]).

trans-unit.source: Optionally, add extensions to your PHP runtime and enable them in the php.ini file.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, add extensions to your PHP runtime and enable them in the php.ini file.

trans-unit.source: Add a bin directory to your root directory, and put the directory that contains your PHP runtime in it (for example, bin\php).
trans-unit.target: Add a bin directory to your root directory, and put the directory that contains your PHP runtime in it (for example, bin\php).

trans-unit.source: Deploy your web app.
trans-unit.target: Deploy your web app.

trans-unit.source: Browse to your web app in the Azure Portal and click on the Settings button.
trans-unit.target: Browse to your web app in the Azure Portal and click on the Settings button.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Web App Settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Web App Settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: From the Settings blade select Application Settings and scroll to the Handler mappings section.
trans-unit.target: From the Settings blade select Application Settings and scroll to the Handler mappings section.

trans-unit.source: Add *.php to the Extension field and add the path to the php-cgi.exe executable.
trans-unit.target: Add *.php to the Extension field and add the path to the php-cgi.exe executable.

trans-unit.source: If you put your PHP runtime in the bin directory in the root of you application, the path will be D:\home\site\wwwroot\bin\php\php-cgi.exe.
trans-unit.target: If you put your PHP runtime in the bin directory in the root of you application, the path will be D:\home\site\wwwroot\bin\php\php-cgi.exe.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Specify handler in hander mappings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Specify handler in hander mappings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the Save button at the top of the Web app settings blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the Save button at the top of the Web app settings blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Save configuration settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Save configuration settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: What's changed
trans-unit.target: What's changed

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <link><linkText>Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <link><linkText>Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: <link><linkText>Reference for navigating the preview portal</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: <link><linkText>Reference for navigating the preview portal</linkText><title></title></link>
